text: From the rising of the sun unto the going down of the same the LORD'S name is to be praised.
text_kjv: From the rising of the sun unto the going down of the same the LORD'S name is to be praised.
text_niv: From the rising of the sun to the place where it sets,the name of the Lord is to be praised.
text_esv: From the rising of the sun to its setting, the name of the LORD is to be praised!
text_nlt: Everywhere — from east to west —praise the name of the LORD.
text_msg: From east to west, from dawn to dusk,keep lifting all your praises to God!
text_nasb: From the rising of the sun to its setting The name of the LORD is to be praised.
context: Psalm 113 is the first of six Psalms (113-118) known as the Egyptian Hallel. These Psalms were traditionally sung during Passover, Pentecost, and the Feast of Tabernacles, significant Jewish festivals. Understanding this liturgical context illuminates the verse's intent. During these feasts, the people remembered God's deliverance from Egypt, reflecting on His faithfulness and power. The phrase 'from the rising of the sun to its going down' represents the entirety of the day, encompassing all times and places. It's a deliberate expansion beyond a localized or occasional act of praise. In ancient Near Eastern cultures, the sun held significant symbolic weight, often associated with deities and worldly power. By stating that the Lord's name should be praised from sunrise to sunset, the Psalmist implicitly asserts Yahweh's supremacy over all other deities and earthly authorities. The repetition emphasizes the continuous and ubiquitous nature of God's worthiness of praise. It highlights that praise isn't confined to specific rituals or locations but is a constant reality that should permeate daily life. Knowing that this Psalm was sung during feasts also gives context. These were times of great joy and thankfulness. It was natural for such a Psalm, calling for the universal praise of God, to be sung in community at these times. The cultural practice of singing together created a shared experience of worship, strengthening the sense of community and shared faith.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 113:3 asserts the universal sovereignty and omnipresence of God. The phrase 'from the rising of the sun unto the going down of the same' symbolizes the entirety of the earth and the duration of a single day, signifying that God's reign extends over all creation and all time. It's a declaration that Yahweh's dominion is not limited to a specific geographical region or a particular segment of time but encompasses the whole world and every moment within it. The Psalmist is not just suggesting praise during sunrise and sunset as symbolic moments, but using these as endpoints to define 'all the time'. The command to praise 'the LORD's name' underscores the importance of reverence and acknowledgment of God's character and attributes. God's name in Hebrew tradition represents His very essence and being. Praising His name is therefore an affirmation of His nature, power, and goodness. It is not merely a vocal exercise but a recognition of His inherent worthiness. This verse connects to the broader biblical theme of God's universal call to worship. While God chose Israel as His covenant people, His ultimate plan includes the redemption of all nations. The call to praise extending from sunrise to sunset foreshadows the fulfillment of this plan, where people from every tribe and tongue will worship Him. The continuous nature of the praise ('is to be praised') suggests an ongoing, active response to God's grace and power. It signifies a commitment to recognizing and celebrating God's presence in every aspect of life.
application: Practically, Psalm 113:3 serves as a constant reminder to cultivate an attitude of praise in our daily lives. It challenges us to move beyond compartmentalizing our worship to Sundays or special occasions and to integrate praise into every moment, 'from sunrise to sunset.' This means actively looking for opportunities to acknowledge God's goodness throughout the day, whether it's expressing gratitude for blessings, recognizing His presence in difficult circumstances, or simply marveling at the beauty of creation. We can practically apply this verse by establishing daily habits of praise. This could involve starting the day with a prayer of thanksgiving, taking moments throughout the day to reflect on God's blessings, or ending the day with a review of God's faithfulness. It might involve creating a 'praise journal' to document instances where we've witnessed God's hand at work. Beyond personal habits, we can also implement this verse in our interactions with others. This could mean speaking positively about God's actions, sharing testimonies of His faithfulness, or encouraging others to recognize His presence in their own lives. Praising God doesn’t always have to be a verbal expression; it can also manifest in our actions. Living a life that reflects God's values and principles is a powerful form of praise. Demonstrating love, compassion, and justice in our interactions with others honors God and points them to Him. This verse calls us to be intentional about making praise a central aspect of our lives, shaping our attitudes, actions, and relationships. The 'rising' and 'setting' of the sun mark significant points in each day, serving as natural prompts for reflection and praise. Use these moments to actively praise God each day.
prayer: Heavenly Father, Your word declares that Your name is to be praised from sunrise to sunset. Forgive me for the times I have neglected to acknowledge Your goodness throughout the day. Help me to cultivate a heart of gratitude and to recognize Your presence in every moment. I praise you for the rising sun, a symbol of Your new mercies each morning. I praise you for the setting sun, a reminder of Your faithfulness that endures through the night. Help me to be a constant reflection of Your love and grace to those around me. May my words and actions be a testament to Your glory. Guide me to see opportunities to praise You in the ordinary moments of each day, and to share Your love with all whom I encounter. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: The phrase is used to denote the entirety of the day, from beginning to end. It emphasizes the continuous and ubiquitous nature of God's worthiness of praise. It indicates that praise is not limited to specific times or places but should permeate all of life.

faqs.answer: Praising the Lord's name is more than just saying His name. In Hebrew tradition, a name represents the very essence and character of a person. To praise God's name is to acknowledge and celebrate His attributes, power, and goodness.
